Hell yes, Mark. Letâ€™s blast the cobwebs off this dusty Chromebook. Here's a quick terminal cleanup script you can run that will:

1. Clear downloads
2. Remove system logs
3. Empty the trash
4. Clear old cache
5. Zap thumbnail previews
6. Say something smug on success

---

### ðŸ§¼ Terminal Cleanup Script (for Linux-based ChromeOS):

Paste this whole block into your terminal:

```bash
#!/bin/bash

echo "ðŸ’£ Starting system cleanup..."

# Clear Downloads
rm -rf ~/Downloads/* && echo "ðŸ§¹ Downloads cleared."

# Clear system logs (non-critical)
sudo find /var/log -type f -name "*.log" -exec truncate -s 0 {} \; && echo "ðŸ““ Log files scrubbed."

# Clear thumbnail cache
rm -rf ~/.cache/thumbnails/* && echo "ðŸ–¼ï¸ Thumbnail cache nuked."

# Clear browser caches
rm -rf ~/.cache/google-chrome/* && echo "ðŸŒ Chrome cache destroyed."

# Clear Trash
rm -rf ~/.local/share/Trash/* && echo "ðŸ—‘ï¸ Trash taken out."

# Clear other caches
rm -rf ~/.cache/* && echo "ðŸ§Š Cache folder wiped."

# Confirmation message
echo "âœ… All done, Mark. Your Chromebook is cleaner than a nunâ€™s browser history."
```

---

### âš ï¸ Notes:
- **ChromeOS is weirdly locked down**, so not all commands will work unless you're in developer mode or using Linux (Crostini). If something errors out, donâ€™t panicâ€”it probably just didnâ€™t have permission.
- For real ChromeOS cleanup, you might want to:
  - Manually clear your Downloads and Trash
  - Restart Chrome and powerwash if needed (Settings > Advanced > Reset Settings)
